subject: Business
title: Hyperinflation in Weimar Germany
description: A 60-second lesson on Hyperinflation in Weimar Germany.

hook.text: In 1923, a loaf of bread in Berlin cost 200 billion marks. Workers carried wages in wheelbarrows.

buildup.text: After World War I, Germany owed massive reparations. The government printed money to pay debts.

discovery.text: Prices doubled every few days. People spent money the instant they received it because waiting meant it was worthless.

twist.text: The middle class was wiped out. Savings became worthless overnight. Social trust collapsed.

climax.text: Stability returned only when Germany introduced a new currency backed by land and mortgages â€” the Rentenmark.

punchline.text: Print enough money and money becomes meaningless.

quiz.question: What caused Weimar Germany's hyperinflation?
options: The government printed massive amounts of money to pay war reparations
A gold shortage caused prices to rise
Foreign banks manipulated the exchange rate
